Predicting Shares from Estimated Models

Source: vignettes/predict_shares.Rmd
predict_shares.Rmd

Once a model has been estimated, it can be used to predict the expected shares for a set of alternatives. This vignette demonstrates examples of how to so using the simulateShares() function along with the results of an estimated model.

The data

To simulate shares, you first need to create a set of alternatives where each row is an alternative and each column an attribute. In this example, I just use a couple of the choice observations from the yogurt dataset (note that if you include more than one set of alternatives you also have to specify an obsID):

alts <- subset(yogurt, obsID %in% c(42, 13),
               select = c('obsID', 'price', 'feat', 'brand'))
alts
#>     obsID price feat   brand
#> 49     13   8.1    0  dannon
#> 50     13   5.0    0  hiland
#> 51     13   8.6    0  weight
#> 52     13  10.8    0 yoplait
#> 165    42   6.3    0  dannon
#> 166    42   6.1    1  hiland
#> 167    42   7.9    0  weight
#> 168    42  11.5    0 yoplait

Predicting shares with multinomial logit models

Preference space parameterization

In the example below, I estimate a preference space MNL model called mnl_pref. I can then use the predictShares() function with the mnl_pref model to predict the shares for each set of alternatives in the alts data frame:

# Estimate the model
mnl_pref <- logitr(
  data       = yogurt,
  choiceName = 'choice',
  obsIDName  = 'obsID',
  parNames   = c('price', 'feat', 'brand')
)

# Predict shares
shares_mnl_pref <- predictShares(
  model     = mnl_pref,
  alts      = alts,
  obsIDName = "obsID",
  alpha     = 0.025
)
shares_mnl_pref
#>   obsID share_mean  share_low share_high
#> 1    13 0.43684871 0.39183474 0.48012387
#> 2    13 0.03313009 0.02561765 0.04250914
#> 3    13 0.19155738 0.17158364 0.21133817
#> 4    13 0.33846382 0.28127798 0.39966501
#> 5    42 0.60763975 0.54555376 0.66201521
#> 6    42 0.02602079 0.01853393 0.03598172
#> 7    42 0.17803594 0.16275146 0.19330784
#> 8    42 0.18830353 0.13783045 0.24939036

The results show the expected shares for each alternative. The low and high values show a 95% confidence interval estimated using the Krinsky and Robb parametric bootstrapping method (Krinsky and Robb 1986). You can change the CI level by setting alpha to a different value (e.g. a 90% CI is obtained with alpha = 0.05).

WTP space parameterization

You can also use WTP space models to predict shares, but you must provide the additional priceName argument to the predictShares() function. For example, here are the results from an equivalent model but in the WTP space:

# Estimate the model
mnl_wtp <- logitr(
  data       = yogurt,
  choiceName = 'choice',
  obsIDName  = 'obsID',
  parNames   = c('feat', 'brand'),
  priceName  = 'price',
  modelSpace = 'wtp',
  options = list(numMultiStarts = 10)
)

# Predict shares
shares_mnl_wtp <- predictShares(
  model     = mnl_wtp,
  alts      = alts,
  obsIDName = "obsID",
  priceName = 'price'
)
#> NOTE: Using results from run 8 of 10 multistart runs
#> (the run with the largest log-likelihood value)
shares_mnl_wtp
#>   obsID share_mean  share_low share_high
#> 1    13 0.43685988 0.41524596 0.45769403
#> 2    13 0.03312953 0.02662358 0.04218726
#> 3    13 0.19154714 0.17633901 0.20805002
#> 4    13 0.33846344 0.31847763 0.35839395
#> 5    42 0.60767025 0.57562381 0.63647737
#> 6    42 0.02601826 0.01896944 0.03753264
#> 7    42 0.17802280 0.16180881 0.19529024
#> 8    42 0.18828870 0.16716593 0.20963707

Since these two models are equivalent except in different spaces, the predicted share results should be the same.

Predicting with mixed logit models

Preference space parameterization

You can also use mixed logit models to predict shares. Heterogeneity is modeled by simulating draws from the population estimates of the estimated model. Here is an example using a preference space mixed logit model:

# Estimate the model
mxl_pref <- logitr(
  data       = yogurt,
  choiceName = 'choice',
  obsIDName  = 'obsID',
  parNames   = c('price', 'feat', 'brand'),
  randPars   = c(feat = 'n', brand = 'n'),
  options    = list(numMultiStarts = 5)
)

# Predict shares
shares_mxl_pref <- predictShares(
  model     = mxl_pref,
  alts      = alts,
  obsIDName = "obsID"
)
shares_mxl_pref
#>   obsID share_mean  share_low share_high
#> 1    13 0.45230084 0.34685782 0.53777632
#> 2    13 0.02782708 0.02130058 0.08857725
#> 3    13 0.21027296 0.07357955 0.33470112
#> 4    13 0.30959912 0.24911607 0.38138551
#> 5    42 0.60391759 0.43773028 0.73095720
#> 6    42 0.06797893 0.02778536 0.14512204
#> 7    42 0.18726035 0.05988838 0.31253601
#> 8    42 0.14084313 0.10510638 0.22055901

WTP space parameterization

Likewise, mixed logit WTP space models can also be used to predict shares:

# Estimate the model
mxl_wtp <- logitr(
  data       = yogurt,
  choiceName = 'choice',
  obsIDName  = 'obsID',
  parNames   = c('feat', 'brand'),
  priceName  = 'price',
  randPars   = c(feat = 'n', brand = 'n'),
  modelSpace = 'wtp',
  options    = list(numMultiStarts = 5)
)

# Predict shares
shares_mxl_wtp <- predictShares(
  model     = mxl_wtp,
  alts      = alts,
  obsIDName = "obsID",
  priceName = 'price'
)
shares_mxl_wtp
#>   obsID share_mean  share_low share_high
#> 1    13 0.44009485 0.36621451 0.49939248
#> 2    13 0.02680642 0.02101409 0.07080935
#> 3    13 0.20352286 0.08488655 0.31623897
#> 4    13 0.32957587 0.27774262 0.38700050
#> 5    42 0.58694687 0.47477206 0.67250021
#> 6    42 0.08160428 0.03337562 0.16703504
#> 7    42 0.18184019 0.07148755 0.29195252
#> 8    42 0.14960865 0.11690293 0.20051650

Compare results

Here is a bar chart comparing the predicted shares from each model:

library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)

shares <- rbind(
  shares_mnl_pref, shares_mnl_wtp, shares_mxl_pref, shares_mxl_wtp) %>%
  mutate(
    model = c(rep("mnl_pref", 8), rep("mnl_wtp", 8),
              rep("mxl_pref", 8), rep("mxl_wtp", 8)),
    alt = rep(c("dannon", "hiland", "weight", "yoplait"), 8),
    obs = paste0("Observation ID: ", obsID)
  )

ggplot(shares, aes(x = alt, y = share_mean, fill = model)) +
    geom_bar(stat = 'identity', width = 0.7, position = "dodge") +
    geom_errorbar(aes(ymin = share_low, ymax = share_high),
                  width = 0.2, position = position_dodge(width = 0.7)) +
    facet_wrap(vars(obs)) +
    scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 1)) +
    labs(x = 'Alternative', y = 'Expected Share') +
    theme_bw()

References

Krinsky, Itzhak, and A Leslie Robb. 1986. “On Approximating the Statistical Properties of Elasticities.” The Review of Economics and Statistics, 715–19.
